lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 11, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project dialog first)
1. Set up the correct JDK version, as follows:
1. Click `Configure` > `Structure for New Projects` and then `Project Settings` > `Project` > `Project SDK`
1. If JDK 11 is listed in the drop down, select it. If it is not, click `New...` and select the directory where you installed JDK 11
1. Import the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.

1. After the importing is complete, locate the `src/main/java/duke.Duke.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run duke.Duke.main()`. If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below:
* The Duke program accepts user inputs to add and store different types of tasks in a list.
* Users can also search for tasks, mark them as completed, delete them, or display the current
* list of tasks. Whenever changes are made to the task list, the text file used for storing the
* task list is updated. Upon termination of the Duke program, the task list will be retained
* in this text file. When the Duke program is run again, the same task list will be loaded from
// Represents the index position of the most recently added task in the task list.
// This is used for getting tasks from a file.
private static final String PATH = "data" + File.separator + "duke.txt";

* @throws DukeEmptyDescriptionException if the user does not input a description for the task.
public void addToList(String fullCommand, String taskType) throws DukeEmptyDescriptionException,

* Copies the tasks of the current task list which contain the user-specified search phrase into a new task list and
* returns this new list. This list can be empty if no tasks contain the search phrase.
* @return a task list containing only tasks that contain the search phrase.

* changes to the task list when they occur.
* Reads a line of user input and returns it.
* @return a line of user input as a String.

* @param deletedTask the Task object that was deleted from the task list.
* @param tasks the TaskList object containing the task list.
public void showTaskDeleted(Task deletedTask, TaskList tasks) {
System.out.printf("\tYou now have %d task(s) in your list, sir.\n", tasks.getTasks().size());
* Prints an error message when the user-specified task number is outside the range of existing task numbers.
System.out.println("\tThat task number is not in your list, sir.");
* Prints an error message when storage file for the task list cannot be found.
System.out.println("\tduke.txt does not exist in /data folder!");
* Prints an error message when the user-specified task number is not an integer.
System.out.println("\t" + Emojis.SAD_EMOJI + " I don't recognise that task number, sir. Please enter a valid" +
* Prints the task that was marked as completed.
* @param taskDone the Task object that was marked as completed.
System.out.println("\t" + Emojis.CLAP_EMOJI + " Very good, sir. Excellent work accomplishing your task:");
* Prints an error message when the user fails to specify a description of a task.
System.out.println("\t" + Emojis.SAD_EMOJI + " Apologies, sir. The description of your task cannot be empty.");
* Prints an error message when the user fails to input "/by" for deadlines or "/at" for events.
System.out.println("\t" + Emojis.SAD_EMOJI + " Please ensure that your deadline or event is followed by"
* Prints the task added to the task list.
* @param tasks the TaskList object containing the task list.
System.out.println("\t" + Emojis.OKAY_EMOJI + " Understood, sir. I've added this task: ");
System.out.printf("\tYou currently have %d task(s) in your list, sir.%n", tasks.getTasks().size());
* Prints the entire task list. Prints a different message if the task list is empty.
* @param tasks the TaskList object containing the task list.
System.out.println("\t" + Emojis.HURRAY_EMOJI + " You have no tasks recorded, sir. Huzzah!");
System.out.println("\t" + Emojis.LIST_EMOJI + " Here are your tasks, sir: ");
* Prints a goodbye message upon termination of the program.
System.out.println("\t" + Emojis.SMILE_EMOJI + " Always a pleasure, sir. Do come back soon.");
* Prints the logo of the program.
* Prints the welcome message for when the program begins.
System.out.println("\t" + Emojis.WAVE_EMOJI + " Greetings, sir. My name is Duke");
System.out.println("\tHow may I assist you today, sir?");
* Prints an error message for when there are no valid keywords found in the user input.
System.out.println("\t" + Emojis.CONFUSED_EMOJI + " I'm afraid I don't understand, sir. Please preface " +
"your tasks " + "\n\twith 'todo', 'deadline', or 'event' to add them to your list.");
* Prints an error message for when the inputted date for the deadline is in the wrong format.
System.out.println("\tPlease ensure that your date is in the correct format (YYYY-MM-DD).");

* Contains several emojis that can be printed on the screen.
public static final String SAD_EMOJI = new String(Character.toChars(0x1f61e));
public static final String CLAP_EMOJI = new String(Character.toChars(0x1f44f));
public static final String OKAY_EMOJI = new String(Character.toChars(0x1f44c));
public static final String HURRAY_EMOJI = new String(Character.toChars(0x1f64c));
public static final String LIST_EMOJI = new String(Character.toChars(0x1f4dd));
public static final String SMILE_EMOJI = new String(Character.toChars(0x1f600));
public static final String WAVE_EMOJI = new String(Character.toChars(0x1f64b));
public static final String CONFUSED_EMOJI = new String(Character.toChars(0x1f615));
* Represents a command for adding tasks into the task list.
* Constructs an AddCommand object given the full user input.
* Identifies the keyword in the user input and accordingly determines the task type to be added.
* Adds a new task to the task list. After this task is added to the list, it is printed onto
* the screen. Then, the file used for storing tasks is updated with this task.
* @param tasks the object storing the list of tasks.
* @param ui the Ui object of the current program.
* @param storage the object for writing and reading of the storage file.
* @throws DukeEmptyDescriptionException if user does not give a description of the task.
* @throws IOException if writing to the file fails.
public void execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws DukeEmptyDescriptionException, IOException {
* An abstract class for executing different commands in the Duke program.
public abstract void execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws IOException, DukeEmptyDescriptionException;
* Represents a command for marking existing tasks as completed.
* Marks an existing task in the task list as completed. The task is then printed
* on the screen. Next, the file used for storing tasks is updated.
* @param tasks the object for storing the list of tasks.
* @param ui the Ui object of the current program.
* @param storage the object for writing and reading of the storage file.
* @throws IOException if writing to the file fails.
public void execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws IOException {
* Represents a command for deleting tasks from the task list.
* Deletes an existing task specified by the user. The deleted task is printed
* on the screen. Then, the file storing the task list is updated.
* @param tasks the object for storing the list of tasks.
* @param ui the Ui object of the current program.
* @param storage the object for writing and reading of the storage file.
* @throws IOException if writing to the file fails.
public void execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws IOException {

* Sets the isExit attribute to true. When control is returned
* to the run method in the Duke class, the run

* @param ui the Ui object of the current program.

* Represents a command that searches the task list for tasks that contain the search phrase.
* Prints the matching tasks from the task list that contain the user-specified search phrase.

* @throws DukeEmptyDescriptionException if the user fails to input a description of the task.
* @throws IOException if there is a problem related to the storage file.
public void execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws DukeEmptyDescriptionException, IOException {
* Represents a command to display the current list of tasks.

* @param storage the object for writing and reading of the storage file.
public void execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
* An exception that arises when the user does not input a description of a task.

* Represents a deadline, which is a task to be completed by a specified date.
* @param description the description of the deadline.
* @param by the date by which the deadline is to be completed.
* Returns the deadline in a particular format for printing.
* @return the deadline with the specified date as a String.
* Represents an event, which is a task that will occur at a specified date.
* @param description the description of the event.
* @param at the date of the event.
* Returns the event in a particular format for printing.
* @return the event with the specified date as a String.
* Represents a task, which has a description and a status of completion. The task is
* either completed or not, so the status of completion is either true or false.
* @param description the description of the task.
* Returns the task's status icon, which represents the status of completion. A tick symbol
* is for completed tasks, while a cross is for uncompleted tasks.
* @return the status icon of the task as a String.
* Returns the task in a particular format for printing.
* @return the task with the specified description as a String.
* Represents a to-do, which is a task to be done.
* @param description the description of the to-do.
* Returns the to-do in a particular format for printing.
